problems.title: Even or Odd
problems.description:
Write a program that reads an integer N and prints whether it is Even or Odd.

Input Format
```
N
```

Output Format
Print exactly: Even or Odd
```
Even
```

Constraints
• −10^9 ≤ N ≤ 10^9
• Capital first letter, exact spelling.

Sample Input 1
```
10
```

Sample Output 1
```
Even
```

Sample Input 2
```
7
```

Sample Output 2
```
Odd
```

Explanation
10 % 2 = 0 → Even
7 % 2 = 1 → Odd
problems.hint: Use modulo operator % to check remainder.
problems.explanation:
A number is even if dividing it by 2 has no remainder; odd otherwise.

Step-by-step:
1. Read n.
2. Compute n % 2 (remainder when divided by 2).
3. If remainder is 0 → print Even.
4. If remainder is not 0 → print Odd.

This works for both positive and negative integers.

Example: n=4 → 4%2=0 → Even
Example: n=7 → 7%2=1 → Odd

problems.title: Largest of Three
problems.description:
Write a program that reads three integers and prints the largest.

Input Format
```
a b c
```

Output Format
Print the largest value.
```
max
```

Constraints
• −10^9 ≤ a, b, c ≤ 10^9

Sample Input 1
```
10 55 23
```

Sample Output 1
```
55
```

Sample Input 2
```
100 20 30
```

Sample Output 2
```
100
```

Explanation
55 > 23 > 10 → 55
100 > 30 > 20 → 100
problems.hint: Compare each pair. Max is the one greater than both others.
problems.explanation:
To find the largest of three numbers, compare them in pairs.

Step-by-step:
1. Assume a is the largest (max = a).
2. If b > max, update max = b.
3. If c > max, update max = c.
4. Print max.

Shorthand using nested ternary:
max = (a>=b && a>=c) ? a : (b>=c ? b : c)

Example: a=5, b=9, c=3
max=5 → 9>5 → max=9 → 3<9 (skip) → print 9

problems.title: Grading System
problems.description:
Write a program that reads marks M (0–100) and prints the grade.

Grading Rules
• 90 and above → A
• 80 to 89 → B
• 70 to 79 → C
• Below 70 → F

Input Format
```
M
```

Output Format
```
A
```

Constraints
• 0 ≤ M ≤ 100

Sample Input 1
```
85
```

Sample Output 1
```
B
```

Sample Input 2
```
95
```

Sample Output 2
```
A
```

Explanation
85 is between 80–89 → B
95 is ≥ 90 → A
problems.hint: Use if-else if chain to check mark ranges.
problems.explanation:
Map a numeric score to a letter grade using if-else if conditions.

Grading ranges:
- 90-100 → A
- 80-89 → B
- 70-79 → C
- 60-69 → D
- Below 60 → F

Step-by-step:
1. Read the marks.
2. Check from highest to lowest range using if-else if.
3. Print the corresponding grade.

Tip: Check in descending order (A first) to avoid overlap errors.

problems.title: Leap Year
problems.description:
Check if year Y is a leap year. Print Leap or Not Leap.

Leap Year Rules
• Divisible by 400 → Leap
• Divisible by 4 AND NOT 100 → Leap
• Otherwise → Not Leap

Input Format
```
Y
```

Output Format
```
Leap
```
or
```
Not Leap
```

Constraints
• 1 ≤ Y ≤ 9999

Sample Input 1
```
2000
```

Sample Output 1
```
Leap
```

Sample Input 2
```
1900
```

Sample Output 2
```
Not Leap
```

Explanation
2000: divisible by 400 → Leap
1900: divisible by 100 but not 400 → Not Leap
problems.explanation:
A leap year occurs on a specific schedule to keep calendars aligned with Earth's orbit.

Rules (apply in this exact order):
1. If divisible by 400 → Leap Year (e.g., 2000 is a leap year).
2. Else if divisible by 100 → NOT a Leap Year (e.g., 1900 is not).
3. Else if divisible by 4 → Leap Year (e.g., 2024 is a leap year).
4. Else → NOT a Leap Year (e.g., 2023 is not).

Shorthand: (year%400==0) || (year%4==0 && year%100!=0)

Examples:
2000: 2000%400=0 → Yes
1900: 1900%100=0 but 1900%400≠0 → No
2024: 2024%4=0 and 2024%100≠0 → Yes
2023: 2023%4≠0 → No
